page.title: 03LITTLE WOODBURY Nr SALISBURY
page.content: This iron age farmstead of about 16 hectares was enclosed by a timber palisade in the 4th century B.C., which was replaced by a defensive bank and ditch in the 2nd century.Inside were 2 large circular huts 48ft and 36ft in diameter,made mainly from timber and probably thatched. These were the farmhouses. The many pits and small timber buildings were probably used for grain storage. Barley was the main crop and the threshing was done on flat areas called{'working hollows' and the grain was ground between flat stones. Spinning and weaving were also done on the site. The site was excavated in 1938 by Prof.G. Bersu for the Prehestoric soc. Nothing can now be seen at ground level. No traces of the field system survived,but there are good examples of iron age fields in other parts of the Salisbury area.
